attributes.title: Carley Rose's Final Project
attributes.description: Experimental study testing the effect of gender and alcohol education on future risky drinking behavior.

q1.value: Carley Rose, Clare Conry-Murray, Mackenzie Gillen, Thomas Joseph Harrison

q2.value: Males will report riskier future drinking behavior than females when presented with or without the alcohol long-term effect facts.  Both males and females will report less risky future drinking behavior when presented with the alcohol long-term effect facts.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: I am posting a link on social media so participants can follow the link to fill out the survey. The survey includes demographics, a measure of year in school, and two between-subject conditions indicating alcohol long-term effect facts. Participants will be assigned to their group based on the last digit of their phone number.

attributes.title: Madeline Eickman
attributes.description: There has been little to no research in regards to how desire for a long-term romantic relationship interacts with attractiveness or initial attraction. The current study aims to fill the gap between desire of long-term and short-term romantic relationships on dating experiences and initial attractiveness.

q1.value: Madeline Eickman, Clare Conry-Murray, Mackenzie Gillen, Thomas Joseph Harrison

q2.value: It is hypothesized that there will be a main effect on gender with regards to number of profiles rated attractive such that women will rate more profiles attractive than men. It is also hypothesized that the profiles who seek a long-term relationship will have higher rates of attraction than those seeking a short-term relationship.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This study will contain “dating profiles,” which will consist of a photograph and a brief biography of a person, which includes what the profile is looking for (either a long or short-term relationship). These profiles will be given to 2 groups, one with all profiles wanting long-term relationship and one with all wanting short-term relationships, to be judged whether the participant found the profile attractive or not. This study is a 2 by 2 between subject design with 2 levels.

q7.value: Participants will be asked the last digit of their phone number, which randomly separates into profiles that seek a long-term relationship (group 1) and profiles that do not (group 2).

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q9.value: As owner of the survey, I can access the survey and see how many people have taken it and each person's individual answer. I have only seen how many participants are male and female and how many people have answered each questions.

question.value: Collection will be done via survey from Google Sheets. Particpants younger than 18 and older than 25 will be discarded. Additionally, participants who did not fill out the personal questions section will also be discarded.

q11.value: My target is 80 participants; I will analyze 120 participants.

question.value: One group will have profiles with photographs and a biography stating a desire for a long-term relationship and one group with the same pictures, but with biographies stating a desire for a short-term relationship.

This study will measure the amount of profiles a participant found attractive (from 0-5). Attraction will be considered both physical attraction and whether the participants would hypothetically pursue a relationship with the profile.
The statistical model will be a one-way ANOVA analysis and a chi-square analysis.

q18.value: I will recode all nominal data, which includes gender, ethnicity, college student status, and answers from personal questions section.

q20.value: Outliers will be discarded, all data from that participant will not be used in analysis.

q21.value: Missing data will be entered as ".".

attributes.title: Replication of Cialdini et al., 1990, Study 3
attributes.description:
We are conducting a replicating of Study 2 from Cialdini, Reno and Kallgren (1990). The study investigates conformity to social norms via norm activation (i.e. salience). We are interested in three conditions of Study 2, namely the clean condition, 1 piece of litter, and fully littered condition (conceptually replicated by Cialdinis et al, 1990 Study 3).
 
Study 2 supported that participants are more likely to litter as the amount of littering increases in the environment. Importantly, Study 2 found that people were least likely to litter in a condition including one single piece of litter rather than the clean environment.

The authors explained the effects as saliency of descriptive norms, such that a fully littered environment signals that other people are littering in this environment, while a clean environment signals that people do not litter in this environment. The one piece of litter also signals that other people do not litter in this environment, but the norm is made more salient in this condition than the clean condition due to the one person who has littered. Hence, saliency of the anti-litter norm is strongest in the setting with one piece of litter.

We are replicating this study in a supermarket: placing fliers on “self-scanners”, manipulating the environment (clean, 1 littered flier, and 8 littered fliers), and observing participants frequency of littering the flier.

item1.value:
We are conducting a replicating of Study 2 from Cialdini, Reno and Kallgren (1990). The study investigates conformity to social norms via norm activation (i.e. salience). We are interested in three conditions of Study 2, namely the clean condition, 1 piece of litter, and fully littered condition (conceptually replicated by Cialdinis et al, 1990 Study 3).
 
Study 2 supported that participants are more likely to litter as the amount of littering increases in the environment. Importantly, Study 2 found that people were least likely to litter in a condition including one single piece of litter rather than the clean environment.

The authors explained the effects as saliency of descriptive norms, such that a fully littered environment signals that other people are littering in this environment, while a clean environment signals that people do not litter in this environment. The one piece of litter also signals that other people do not litter in this environment, but the norm is made more salient in this condition than the clean condition due to the one person who has littered. Hence, saliency of the anti-litter norm is strongest in the setting with one piece of litter.

We are replicating this study in a supermarket: placing fliers on “self-scanners”, manipulating the environment (clean, 1 littered flier, and 8 littered fliers), and observing participants frequency of littering the flier.

item2.value: Cialdini et al 1990 is a well cited study that has not been replicated before. The theoretical basis for the normative effect has further not been explicitly tested before.

item3.value: To calculate effect size is based on Study 3, as we are interested in the contrast between the clean, 1 piece of litter and fully littered conditions. The effect size for the difference between the clean and fully littered condition was Cohen’s w = .21, the effect size for the difference between the clean and single piece of litter was Cohen’s w = .14.

item5.value: The total sample size of Study 2 was 258 participants, 59-60 participants for each condition.

item6.value: The original study was a field experiment, conducted in an amusement park.

item7.value: The original study was conducted in the United States.

item8.value: The original study included a sample of visitors to an amusement park.

item9.value: The original study was a field experiment, with observational data.

item11.value: The materials are sufficiently outlined in the original study.

item13.value: The researchers involved in the data collection will all be aware of the condition they are assigned to code.

item14.value: The researchers involved in the data collection will all be aware of the study hypothesis.

item15.value: Our minimum target sample size is 492 valid observations (164 per condition).

item16.value: An a priori power analysis for a χ2 test (α = .05, 1-β = .80, w = .14, df = 2), using results from Study 3 indicated a required sample size of 492 participants to detect the difference between the smallest planned comparison. Hence, 164 observations for each condition, suggesting a total sample of 492 observations. We aim to collect at least 492 observations and maximally 1000 observations. We will not analyze the data before termination of data collection. The final number depends on number of observations within approved time of conducting observations in the supermarket.

item24.value: We expect that littering will be less frequent in our replication compared to the original study, as people might be less likely to litter indoors (in a supermarket) compared to outdoors (in an amusement park).

item26.value:
Coding:

We will code if the participant are littering the flier from the scanner before entering the supermarket (y/n), or placing the flier on another scanner or in the setting (also littering). We will code for:
1)	If each participant is alone of in a group (code for size of group)
2)	Gender of the participant taking the scanner
3)	Number of people in the area
4)	Distance to closest person in the area (0 - >10 meters)
5)	Littering: no vs. yes (extra information about type of littering if not littered on the floor). In the original study, a participant was considered to litter if she deposited the flier anywhere in the environment. Similarly, we will code disposing the flier on the floor in the supermarket or placing the flier on another scanner (or other object in the setting) as littering.

Additional coding:

Time and date.


Litter:

All conditions will be identical to the original study

Clean – no flier on the floor

1 piece of litter – one flier

For the fully littered environment, we will choose 8 fliers as there was no difference between 8 and 16 flyers in the original setting, and the setting for this replication is smaller (entrance to a super market) compared to the original study conducted in an amusement park.


Flier:

The fliers used in Study 2 in the original article read “Don’t miss tonight´s show”. For the replication, we adapted the flyer to time and space, consisting of a yellow flier 7cm x 5cm (to cover the screen on the scanner) reading “Happy Easter“ (in Swedish “Glad Påsk”

item27.value: We will test the hypotheses as in the original study (Study 3). As exploratory analyses, we will also test whether littering increases when participants are by themselves as compared to in pairs or smaller groups, and whether the effect is moderated by gender (as Study 3 was conducted with exclusively female participants).

item28.value: The replication will be deemed successful if both planned contrasts are significant and in the same direction as the original study (Study 2 and 3).

attributes.title: Exploring cancer patient needs for personalized statistical information
attributes.description:
In this study, we aim to investigate the boundaries of general and personalised statistical information for cancer patients. From earlier research we know that patients increasingly use the internet as a source for information about their disease such as incidence, treatment options, survival outcomes or quality of life after treatments. Usually, such information is communicated by using statistics. With the improvement of technology, such statistical information can be tailored by using characteristics of the individual patient. What is unclear however is if patients actually want to receive such personalised statistics. Additionally, research has shown that information coping styles, levels of anxiety and numeracy skills can all influence general information needs. In this study, we aim to explore cancer patient need for both general and personalised statistical information.

Therefore, the aim of this research is twofold: (1) to investigate the needs of cancer patients for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes, and (2) to determine how individual difference factors of patients (e.g., information coping style, numerical skills, and anxiety levels) are related to their needs.

The main research questions of our project are:
RQ 1: What are cancer patient needs for receiving general and personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?
RQ2: How do individual difference factors relate to cancer patient needs for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?

q1.value: Exploring predictors of cancer patient needs for personalized statistical information: A cross-sectional survey

q2.value: Ruben Vromans, Saar Hommes, Felix Clouth, Emiel Krahmer, Deborah Lo-Fo-Wong

q3.value:
In this study, we aim to investigate the boundaries of general and personalised statistical information needs cancer patients. Earlier research suggests that patients increasingly use the internet as a source for information about their disease such as incidence, treatment options, survival outcomes or quality of life after treatments. Usually, such information is communicated by using statistics. With the improvement of technology, such statistical information can be personalized by using characteristics of the individual patient. What is unclear however is if patients actually want to receive such personalized statistics. Additionally, research has shown that information coping styles, levels of anxiety and numeracy skills can all influence general information needs. 

Therefore, the aim of this research is twofold: (1) to investigate the needs of cancer patients for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes, and (2) to determine how individual difference factors of patients (e.g., information coping style, numerical skills, and anxiety levels) are related to their needs.

The main research questions of our project are:
RQ 1: What are cancer patient needs for receiving general and personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?
RQ2: How do individual difference factors relate to cancer patient needs for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?

q4.value:
In order to answer our research question: "what are the general and personalized statistical information needs of cancer patients?", we hypothesize that:

H1a: There is a (M > 3.0) need for personalized statistics (non directional)
H1b: There is a (M > 3.0) need for general statistics (non directional)

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study uses a cross-sectional survey design.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The study population for the survey will consist of cancer patients and survivors who have been diagnosed with cancer (breast, colorectal, lung or prostate cancer) in the past and who have an account on the Dutch cancer information website Kanker.nl. This website has a scientific panel for which cancer patients and survivors can voluntarily subscribe themselves and indicate they are willing to answers surveys via Kanker.nl. This way, only patients who indicated that they want to participate in scientific studies are being approached. 

A representative of Kanker.nl will send an e-mail (in April 2020) including an announcement of our study and a link to the Qualtrics survey to only those members who have indicated that they are willing to be part of the scientific panel of Kanker.nl and answer surveys via Kanker.nl.

q13.value: Our intended sample size is a total of 200 participants.

question.value:
Need for non-treatment related outcomes
g_need_inc: general statistical information need incidence
p_need_inc: personalized statistical information need incidence
g_need_surv1y: general statistical information need 1 year survival 
p_need_surv1y: personalized statistical information 1 year need survival
g_need_surv5y: general statistical information need 5 year survival 
p_need_surv5y: personalized statistical information 5 year need survival

Need for treatment-related outcomes
g_need_treatsurv1y: general statistical information need 1 year survival 
p_need_treatsurv1y: personalized statistical information 1 year need survival
g_need_treatsurv5y: general statistical information need 5 year survival 
p_need_treatsurv5y: personalized statistical information need 5 year survival
g_need_side: general statistical information need side effects
p_need_side: personalized statistical information need side effects
g_need_rec1y: general statistical information need 1 year recurrence 
p_need_rec1y: personalized statistical information 1 year need recurrence 
g_need_rec5y: general statistical information need 5 year recurrence 
p_need_rec5y: personalized statistical information 5 year need recurrence 
g_need_PF: general statistical information need physical functioning
p_need_PF: personalized statistical information need physical functioning 
g_need_CF: general statistical information need cognitive functioning
p_need_CF: personalized statistical information need cognitive functioning 
g_need_EF: general statistical information need emotional functioning
p_need_EF: personalized statistical information need emotional functioning
g_need_SF: general statistical information need social functioning
p_need_SF: personalized statistical information need social functioning

All items are measured on a 4-point scale (1 = not at all, 2 = a little, 3 = quite a bit, 4 = very much)

Covariates:
- Age (in years)
- Sex (0 = male, 1 = female)
- Numerical skills (Subjective Numeracy Scale (Fagerlin et al., 2007), 8 items, all measured on a 6 point scale; score = 1 - 6)
- Information coping style (Threatening Medical Situations Inventory, van Zuuren et al., 1996), 12 items, all measured on a 5 point scale; 0 = blunting, 1 = monitoring). 
- Level of anxiety (the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale, Spinhoven et al., 1997, 7 items, all measured on a 4 point scale (0-3)).

If applicable, we will combine all relevant outcome measures into a mean score for personalized and general statistical information needs, respectively.

Mean scores for non-treatment related outcomes
p_need_surv = (p_need_surv1y + p_need_surv5y) / 2
g_need_surv = (g_need_surv1y + g_need_surv5y) / 2

Mean scores for treatment-related outcomes
p_need_treatsurv = (p_need_treatsurv1y + p_need_treatsurv5y) / 2
g_need_treatsurv = (g_need_treatsurv1y + g_need_treatsurv5y) / 2
p_need_qol = (p_need_PF + p_need_CF + p_need_EF + p_need_SF) / 4
g_need_qol = (g_need_PF + g_need_CF + g_need_EF + g_need_SF) / 4
p_need_rec = (p_need_rec1y + p_need_rec5y) / 2
g_need_rec =  (g_need_rec1y + g_need_rec5y) / 2

Mean scores overall need for personalized or generic statistics
mean(g_need) = (p_need_inc + p_need_surv + p_need_treatsurv + p_need_side + p_need_rec + p_need_qol) / 6
mean(g_need) = (g_need_inc + g_need_surv + g_need_treatsurv + g_need_side + g_need_rec + g_need_qol) / 6

H1a: There is a need for personalized statistics
one tailed t-test: mean(p_need) > 3

H1b: There is a need for generic statistics
one tailed t-test: mean(g_need) > 3

q21.value:
A p-value <.05 will be considered significant. Bonferroni corrections will be applied for testing H1a and H1b.
H1: one tailed test >3.0

q24.value:
We will run separate one-sample t-tests for the variables incidence, survival, recurrence, treatment-related survival, side effects, or quality of life

H1a: 
one tailed t-test: mean(p_need_[variable]) > 3

H1b: 
one tailed t-test: mean(g_need_[variable]) > 3

variable = inc, surv, rec, treatsurv, side, or qol. A p-value <.05 will be considered significant. Bonferroni corrections will be applied for testing H1a and H1b.

RQ's: We will conduct three-step latent class analysis to identify unobserved classes of patients with similar information needs. All variables labeled as outcome measures will be included as indicators (measurement level will be specified as ordinal). The number of classes will be increased until model fit is sufficient. Model fit will be assessed by the BIC (lowest BIC selected), AIC (lowest AIC selected) and bivariate residuals (lower than 10). The assumption of local independence might be relaxed if benefitial for model fit. If model fit indices are indecisive substantive reasons will be used to determine the optimal number of classes. As a next step, all variables labeled as covariates will be related to the class assignment as distal outcomes using step3 procedure in latentGold.

registration_responses.q1: Exploring predictors of cancer patient needs for personalized statistical information: A cross-sectional survey
registration_responses.q2: Ruben Vromans, Saar Hommes, Felix Clouth, Emiel Krahmer, Deborah Lo-Fo-Wong
registration_responses.q3:
In this study, we aim to investigate the boundaries of general and personalised statistical information needs cancer patients. Earlier research suggests that patients increasingly use the internet as a source for information about their disease such as incidence, treatment options, survival outcomes or quality of life after treatments. Usually, such information is communicated by using statistics. With the improvement of technology, such statistical information can be personalized by using characteristics of the individual patient. What is unclear however is if patients actually want to receive such personalized statistics. Additionally, research has shown that information coping styles, levels of anxiety and numeracy skills can all influence general information needs. 

Therefore, the aim of this research is twofold: (1) to investigate the needs of cancer patients for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes, and (2) to determine how individual difference factors of patients (e.g., information coping style, numerical skills, and anxiety levels) are related to their needs.

The main research questions of our project are:
RQ 1: What are cancer patient needs for receiving general and personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?
RQ2: How do individual difference factors relate to cancer patient needs for receiving personalized statistical information about treatment outcomes?
registration_responses.q4:
In order to answer our research question: "what are the general and personalized statistical information needs of cancer patients?", we hypothesize that:

H1a: There is a (M > 3.0) need for personalized statistics (non directional)
H1b: There is a (M > 3.0) need for general statistics (non directional)
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Our intended sample size is a total of 200 participants.
registration_responses.q21:
A p-value <.05 will be considered significant. Bonferroni corrections will be applied for testing H1a and H1b.
H1: one tailed test >3.0
registration_responses.q24:
We will run separate one-sample t-tests for the variables incidence, survival, recurrence, treatment-related survival, side effects, or quality of life

H1a: 
one tailed t-test: mean(p_need_[variable]) > 3

H1b: 
one tailed t-test: mean(g_need_[variable]) > 3

variable = inc, surv, rec, treatsurv, side, or qol. A p-value <.05 will be considered significant. Bonferroni corrections will be applied for testing H1a and H1b.

RQ's: We will conduct three-step latent class analysis to identify unobserved classes of patients with similar information needs. All variables labeled as outcome measures will be included as indicators (measurement level will be specified as ordinal). The number of classes will be increased until model fit is sufficient. Model fit will be assessed by the BIC (lowest BIC selected), AIC (lowest AIC selected) and bivariate residuals (lower than 10). The assumption of local independence might be relaxed if benefitial for model fit. If model fit indices are indecisive substantive reasons will be used to determine the optimal number of classes. As a next step, all variables labeled as covariates will be related to the class assignment as distal outcomes using step3 procedure in latentGold.

registration_responses.q12.question:
The study population for the survey will consist of cancer patients and survivors who have been diagnosed with cancer (breast, colorectal, lung or prostate cancer) in the past and who have an account on the Dutch cancer information website Kanker.nl. This website has a scientific panel for which cancer patients and survivors can voluntarily subscribe themselves and indicate they are willing to answers surveys via Kanker.nl. This way, only patients who indicated that they want to participate in scientific studies are being approached. 

A representative of Kanker.nl will send an e-mail (in April 2020) including an announcement of our study and a link to the Qualtrics survey to only those members who have indicated that they are willing to be part of the scientific panel of Kanker.nl and answer surveys via Kanker.nl.

attributes.title: Altering the way we operationalize multiracials
attributes.description:
Recent research has found that biracial categorization accuracy is far below monoracial categorization accuracy. This is troublesome for both internal reliability and ecological validity. As a response to the lack of biracial categorizations and reliability in real biracial stimuli, we have developed a set of altered (“biracialized”) faces.

Our recent research has found that perceived “unusualness” or “distinctiveness” of the faces partially explains biracial categorization accuracy. If this is true, then enhanced unusual traits (e.g., eye color, freckles) and the interaction between traits (e.g., blue eyes with darker skin tone) may increase unusualness ratings. Our biracialized faces, altered in photoshop to enhance these unique features, might therefore be a solution to increase biracial categorization accuracy. 

The purpose of our research is to compare our biracialized stimulus set to existing biracial stimuli that are commonly used in the field. Existing research on the racial categorization of biracial individuals has heavily relied on the use of morphed faces to represent real biracial people (Minear & Park, 2004; Peery & Bodenhausen, 2008; Chen & Hamilton, 2012). Morphed faces are usually created using morphing software (e.g. Fantamorph) and combine two monoracial parent faces to create 50/50 morphs. For example, morphs are commonly made by combining a Black face and a White face to create a Black-White biracial face. In morphed stimuli, hair is usually left out of the final image due to the unsatisfactory product of morphing two different hair styles. Therefore, we will test our biracialized stimuli against these cropped morphed faces. We will also test them against real biracial faces from a new expansion to the Chicago Face Database (Ma, Kantner, & Wittenbrink, submitted for publication). 

 Moreover, we also want to examine the underlying factors resulting in categorization differences across face types. The traits we plan to examine are: attractive, unusual (would stand out in a crowd), feminine, baby-faced, and artificial-looking. These are based on existing research in the field and our prior research.

q1.value: Jonathan Benitez, Debbie S. Ma, Justin Kantner, Stephanie Dunn

q2.value:
Our primary goal is to determine the differences in biracial categorization accuracy for our biracialized stimuli, morph faces, and real biracial faces. We predict that our biracialized stimuli will yield the greatest amount of biracial categorizations. We expect that there will be no difference among the two biracialized conditions (cropped and uncropped monoracial distractors), and therefore we may collapse the two. Based on our prior research, we predict morph faces and real biracial faces will have about the same amount of biracial categorizations (~20-25%). 

Further, we want to determine the factors driving differences in participants’ race categorizations. Based on our prior research and the fact that certain physical traits (e.g., eye color, freckles) have been enhanced on our biracialized faces, we predict that they will be rated as more attractive, unusual (would stand out in a crowd), feminine, baby-faced, and artificial-looking than the morphs and real biracial faces.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study will have a one-way between-subjects design. There will be four conditions. The morph stimuli can only appear in cropped form because morphing technology creates unrealistic stimuli if the unnatural hair is included. Therefore, one condition will have cropped (oval masked) morphed faces with cropped (oval masked) monoracial distractors. Another condition will have the same cropped morphed faces but with uncropped (hair included) monoracial distractors. A third condition will have real biracial stimuli, uncropped to include hair, with uncropped monoracial distractors. The last condition will have our biracialized stimuli, uncropped to include hair, with uncropped monoracial distractors. 

Each participant will randomly see and rate 8 biracial faces (among 16 distractor faces), one image at a time, from a possible total of 46 target images per condition.

q7.value: The participants will be randomly assigned to each condition with the randomize option on Qualtrics.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We are collecting our data from the psychology student pool at our university. We will collect data over the course of one month.

q11.value: Based on a power analysis, our sample size will be 920 U.S. based participants.

q12.value: We conducted a power analysis in G*Power for an ANOVA (Fixed effects, omnibus, one-way) with an effect size of 0.30 and power of 0.8 and found we would need 128 participants. However, given the likelihood of some exclusions, we will collect 25% more data. Therefore, we require 160 participants. Because each participant will only rate 8 targets in any given condition, we need 5.75 times the participants. Therefore, we require a total of 920 participants.

question.value: There will be four levels of type of stimuli: real biracial uncropped, morph cropped, and biracialized uncropped (one condition with uncropped monoracial distractors and the other cropped monoracial distractors).

Participants will categorize faces according to 9 race options: Asian, Black, Latino or HIspanic, Native American, Pacific Islander, Middle Eastern, White, Biracial or Multiracial, and Other.

Participants will rate faces according to five traits: attractive, unusual (would stand out in a crowd), feminine, baby-faced, and artificial-looking. Participants will be asked to rate each individual image from “Not at all” to “Extremely” along these five dimensions.

We will also ask participants for demographic information.

We plan to run an ANOVA with planned comparisons. The independent variable will be stimulus type (biracialized, morph, real biracial) and the dependent variables will be biracial categorization accuracy and each of the five trait DVs. We expect to find a significant effect of stimulus type, such that the biracialized faces will be categorized as biracial more often and will also be rated higher in all of the five traits. To counteract the problem of multiple comparisons, we plan to use a post-hoc Tukey test. 

Due to the multilevel nature of our data, in our supplementary material, we plan to include multilevel regression models. The models will include stimulus type (biracialized, morph, real biracial) as a fixed factor, participant and targets as random factors, and biracial categorization and each one of the five DVs as the outcome variable. If the conclusions from these analyses differ from those of the ANOVA and planned comparisons, we will fully disclose this information.

q19.value: An alpha level of .05 will be used to make statistical inferences. We will use two-tailed tests for all of our analyses. We will use a Tukey test for all post-hoc analyses.

q20.value: We plan to exclude any incomplete data. We will only remove participants who provide greater than or equal to 90% of the same responses, on the assumption that these participants were not responding earnestly to the questions. We would also remove bots flagged by captcha.

q21.value: If a participant provides incomplete data, then we will remove the entire case from the data set.

q22.value:
We will explore whether base rate information (i.e., Based on your knowledge of the community where you live, what percentage of people do you guess are biracial or multiracial?”) is related to unusual (would stand out in a crowd) ratings of biracial targets.

We will also be exploring whether interactions of different physical features correspond with higher multiracial classifications. These may be interactions between hair color, hair texture, skin tone, eye color, lip shape, nose shape, and other physical measures.

attributes.title: Kara McSweeney's Final Project
attributes.description: The experiment is investigating if men and women's drinking habits are judged differently and if the gender of the participant influences how harshly they are judged. This will be done through a survey that will ask demographic questions, then give the participants one of two scenarios, one with a woman and one with a man. Both scenarios will have the same wording and drinking tendencies, but different gender. Then, the participant will be asked how respectable the behavior was.

q1.value: Kara McSweeney, Christen Dockins, Maura Flynn, Robert Gentilucci, Amanda Monetti, Corinne O'Neill, Madison Pristera, Caitlyn Pritchard, Ashley Santos, Gabriella Senni, Raymond Zuhowski, Samantha Zupko, Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen, Minka Bolognese, Ella Campbell, Patricia Carballo, Sheahan Collins, Madeline Eickman, Ryenn Hayes, Amanda Herzig, Tess Hodder, Gabriel Legido, Ann McConnon, Michael McDermott, Alyssa McDougall, Claire Pier, Allison Quinter, Carley Rose, Lauren Rossi, Brendan Steigerwald, Nolan Vagnozzi, Alexa Weber

q2.value: There will be a main effect in which women's drinking habits will be judged more harshly than men's drinking habits, even though it is the same behavior, when asking both men and women participants. This means that regardless of the gender of the participant, women will be judged more harshly than men.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: 2 (gender of participant) x 2 (gender of person drinking) between subject

q8.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: I will be sending a link to the survey to many people through text or email, in addition to posting the link on various social media sites. The survey will begin with five demographic questions asking about age, gender, ethnicity, if they are currently attending a college or university, and if they are currently a student at Saint Joseph’s University. Then, the survey will ask if the last digit of their number is odd or even. If the last digit is even, the participant will be directed to Scenario A, which involves a woman drinking, whereas if the last digit is odd, the participant will be directed to Scenario B, which involves a man drinking. Then, they will be asked how respectable is the behavior of the person in situation on a scale from 1-10.

attributes.title: Tess Hodder final project
attributes.description: In the current study, it will be determined if the manner in which the DARE information was presented had an effect on its success rates. It will be experimented in a way in which information is presented to both males and females, either showing scary statistics regarding drugs and alcohol or taking a personal approach and having people relate to real life scenarios. It will be revealed whether they choose to lessen drug and alcohol use after having them apply scenarios to their personal life, or by scaring them away with harsh statistics and facts.

q1.value: Tess Hodder, Christen Dockins, Maura Flynn, Robert Gentilucci, Amanda Monetti, Corinne O'Neill, Madison Pristera, Caitlyn Pritchard, Ashley Santos, Gabriella Senni, Raymond Zuhowski, Samantha Zupko, Clare Conry-Murray, Thomas Joseph Harrison, Mackenzie Gillen, Minka Bolognese, Ella Campbell, Patricia Carballo, Sheahan Collins, Madeline Eickman, Ryenn Hayes, Amanda Herzig, Gabriel Legido, Ann McConnon, Michael McDermott, Alyssa McDougall, Kara McSweeney, Claire Pier, Allison Quinter, Carley Rose, Lauren Rossi, Brendan Steigerwald, Nolan Vagnozzi, Alexa Weber

q2.value: It is hypothesized that there will be a main effect of DARE message delivery (casual versus serious/scary) such that ideas of DARE that are presented to the subject from a casual manner noting that alcohol and drug use are “uncool” will be more effective than DARE presenting information in a serious, authoritative, or even scary fashion. Second, it is hypothesized that there will be a main effect of gender on DV such that males will decrease their likelihood of consuming substances when presented with casual scenarios more than females.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The current study aims to recruit 40 participants, who are 18 years or older. Group 1 will consist of 10 males and 10 females. Group 2 will also consist of 10 males and 10 females. All 20 males and 20 females were placed in a number generator to randomly assign each survey to them. Group 1 will receive Survey 1 (facts/statistics) and group 2 will receive Survey 2 (relatable approach). This experiment is an ‘in-between’ subject experiment, meaning not all participants are presented with all conditions.  Each participant started by answering a few demographics, then rated their likelihood of consuming drugs or alcohol. They will be given a scale from 0(not at all) to 5(very likely) to rate their likelihood in consuming drugs and alcohol.There are 15 boxes of information per survey presented to the subject. As they received each box of information, they continue to press “next” to show they have completed reading that box. In the end, they then had to restate their stance on drug and alcohol use.

q7.value: Group 1 will consist of 10 males and 10 females. Group 2 will also consist of 10 males and 10 females. All 20 males and 20 females were placed in a number generator to randomly assign each survey to them. All participants were chosen from friends that the creator has. It was all random, aside from the participants having to be above the age of 18.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value: The current study aims to recruit 40 participants, who are 18 years or older. They are all from New Jersey, all received full levels of high school education, some are currently enrolled in a college university, and some have graduated with a college degree.  Even though subjects were recruited, they had the option to not complete the survey. Fortunately, all participants did. There are conditions that will not be taken into consideration, which include the subject’s race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, level of education, parent’s attitudes, and whether or not they participated in the D.A.R.E program in their pasts. The experiment is solely concerned with the gender of each subject.

q11.value: The current study aims to recruit 40 participants, who are 18 years or older. Group 1 will consist of 10 males and 10 females. Group 2 will also consist of 10 males and 10 females. Total, 20 males and 20 females.

question.value:
The two independent variables will be two surveys, one including facts and statistics intended to scare the participant, while the other survey includes scenarios and situations that are meant to make the subject feel empathetic and more easily related.  Survey #1 will consist of statements regarding principles from DARE being presented in a serious and authoritative way.
Facts and statistics will be presented in an attempt to intimidate or scare the subject regarding the use of alcohol and drugs. Each statement or question will show statistics, death rates, and the negative effects of drugs/alcohol. Survey #2 will have scenarios presented from the perspective of a friend or peer regarding their attitudes towards drugs/alcohol. The scenarios will show that alcohol/drug use is “uncool”  and have the subjects relate to it on a personal level.
The dependent variable will be the rating in which each participant chooses. They will be given a scale from 0(not at all) to 5(very likely) to rate their likelihood in consuming drugs and alcohol.

The dependent variable will be the rating in which each participant chooses. They will be given a scale from 0(not at all) to 5(very likely) to rate their likelihood in consuming drugs and alcohol. The two independent variables will be two surveys, one including facts and statistics intended to scare the participant, while the other survey includes scenarios and situations that are meant to make the subject feel empathetic and more easily related.
The current experiment will use a one-way between subjects ANOVA to analyze the results. Jamovi programing will also be used to analyze all data.

q2.value: I expect that males will indicate higher levels of happiness in general. Males will show a strong preference toward rap music, and as a result indicate that they feel happy after listening to the rap music video. Females will show a preference toward pop music, and therefore indicate that they feel happy after listening to the pop music video. Overall, pop music will illicit the highest rating of happiness.

question.value: 1. type of music listened to- (classical, pop, country, or rap)

1. After each music video that the participants watch (four in total, corresponding to the four music categories), they will be asked to record their levels of happiness. Levels of happiness were measured on a scale of 1-5 (1 being the least happy, and 5 being the most happy). The range was listed as follows: not happy at all, somewhat happy, happy, very happy, extremely happy. Control was measured by measuring overall mood before listening to the music videos.
2. The second measured variable is gender.

attributes.title: Tweeting with Emotion: News Organizations' Use of Affect on Twitter
attributes.description: This study is an expansion of a previously conducted exploratory pilot study (Bellovary, Young, & Quinn, 2019). We aim to examine how left- and right-leaning news organizations use affective messages on Twitter and how those messages lead to interactions with tweets.

summary.value: We have attached a file that explains our preregistered hypotheses and analysis plan.
